hook.text: Your heart sits left of center, tucked between your lungs.

buildup.text: It weighs about as much as a tennis ball.

discovery.text: Your fist is roughly the same size as your heart.

twist.text: Despite being small, it pumps 2,000 gallons daily.

climax.text: Over a lifetime it beats about three billion times.

punchline.text: A tiny pump with an enormous job.

quiz.question: Roughly how much blood does the heart pump each day?

hook.text: The heart is not one big hollow space inside.

buildup.text: A wall of muscle divides it into left and right sides.

discovery.text: Each side has an atrium on top and a ventricle below.

twist.text: The left ventricle is the strongest chamber of all.

climax.text: It must push blood all the way to your toes and back.

punchline.text: Four rooms, one powerful house.

quiz.question: Which heart chamber is the strongest?

hook.text: Blood must flow in only one direction through the heart.

buildup.text: Four tiny valves open and close with every heartbeat.

discovery.text: They snap shut to stop blood from flowing backward.

twist.text: The lub-dub sound is actually the valves closing.

climax.text: A stethoscope reveals whether they work properly.

punchline.text: Your heartbeat is the sound of doors.

quiz.question: What causes the lub-dub sound of your heartbeat?

hook.text: Your heart does not need your brain to keep beating.

buildup.text: A cluster of cells called the SA node fires on its own.

discovery.text: This natural pacemaker sends an electrical signal each beat.

twist.text: Even removed from the body, a heart keeps beating briefly.

climax.text: Doctors can implant artificial pacemakers when it fails.

punchline.text: The heart writes its own rhythm.

quiz.question: What is the heart's natural pacemaker called?

hook.text: A resting heart beats about 60 to 100 times per minute.

buildup.text: During exercise, muscles demand more oxygen and fuel.

discovery.text: Your heart responds by beating faster and harder.

twist.text: Trained athletes often have resting rates below 50.

climax.text: Their hearts pump more blood per beat, so fewer are needed.

punchline.text: A stronger heart can afford to be lazier.

quiz.question: Why do athletes often have lower resting heart rates?
options: Their hearts pump more per beat

hook.text: Every heartbeat sends a surge of blood outward.

buildup.text: Arteries carry this oxygen-rich blood away from the heart.

discovery.text: Their thick, elastic walls stretch with each pulse.

twist.text: The aorta, the largest artery, is as wide as a garden hose.

climax.text: Arteries branch into smaller vessels reaching every organ.

punchline.text: Highways that stretch with every beat.

quiz.question: What is the largest artery in the human body?

hook.text: After delivering oxygen, blood needs to return home.

buildup.text: Veins carry this used blood back toward the heart.

discovery.text: They have one-way valves that prevent blood from pooling.

twist.text: Leg muscles act as pumps to push blood upward.

climax.text: Standing still too long can cause blood to pool in veins.

punchline.text: Your muscles help pump blood uphill.

quiz.question: What prevents blood from flowing backward in veins?

hook.text: Between arteries and veins lies a hidden network.

buildup.text: Capillaries are so thin that red blood cells pass single file.

discovery.text: Oxygen and nutrients slip through their one-cell walls.

twist.text: Laid end to end, your capillaries would circle Earth twice.

climax.text: Every living cell sits within reach of a capillary.

punchline.text: The smallest vessels do the biggest job.

quiz.question: How thin are capillary walls?

hook.text: A blood pressure reading gives two numbers, not one.

buildup.text: The top number measures force when the heart contracts.

discovery.text: The bottom number measures force when it relaxes.

twist.text: High blood pressure often has zero symptoms for years.

climax.text: It silently damages arteries, kidneys, and the brain.

punchline.text: The silent killer hides in plain sight.

quiz.question: What does the top number in a blood pressure reading measure?

hook.text: Press two fingers on your wrist and you feel something.

buildup.text: Each pulse is a wave of blood pushed by a heartbeat.

discovery.text: You feel it wherever an artery runs close to the skin.

twist.text: Ancient doctors diagnosed illness by pulse alone.

climax.text: Modern sensors track pulse continuously on smartwatches.

punchline.text: An ancient diagnostic tool on your wrist.

quiz.question: What creates the pulse you feel at your wrist?
options: A wave of blood from a heartbeat

hook.text: Your body makes about two million red blood cells per second.

buildup.text: Each one carries a protein called hemoglobin inside it.

discovery.text: Hemoglobin grabs oxygen in the lungs and releases it in tissues.

twist.text: Iron in hemoglobin is what makes your blood look red.

climax.text: Without enough iron, cells starve for oxygen.

punchline.text: Iron is the reason blood is red.

quiz.question: What protein in red blood cells carries oxygen?

hook.text: For every 700 red blood cells, there is one white one.

buildup.text: White blood cells roam the bloodstream hunting invaders.

discovery.text: Some swallow bacteria whole like tiny predators.

twist.text: Pus is actually a pile of dead white blood cells.

climax.text: They sacrifice themselves to protect the body.

punchline.text: Pus is a battlefield graveyard.

quiz.question: What is pus mainly composed of?

hook.text: When you cut yourself, bleeding usually stops in minutes.

buildup.text: Tiny cell fragments called platelets rush to the wound.

discovery.text: They stick together and form a plug over the opening.

twist.text: A protein mesh called fibrin then weaves over the plug.

climax.text: The clot hardens into a scab that protects healing tissue.

punchline.text: Your blood builds its own bandage.

quiz.question: What forms the mesh that strengthens a blood clot?

hook.text: More than half your blood is not cells at all.

buildup.text: Plasma is a yellowish liquid that carries cells and nutrients.

discovery.text: It also transports hormones, waste, and antibodies.

twist.text: Plasma is about 90 percent water by volume.

climax.text: Donated plasma saves lives of burn and trauma victims.

punchline.text: The river that carries everything else.

quiz.question: What percentage of plasma is water?

hook.text: Not all blood is the same when it enters another body.

buildup.text: Surface markers on red cells define your blood type.

discovery.text: The ABO system groups blood into A, B, AB, and O.

twist.text: Type O negative can be given to almost anyone safely.

climax.text: A mismatch triggers the immune system to attack the blood.

punchline.text: The wrong gift can be deadly.

quiz.question: Which blood type is considered the universal donor?

hook.text: Blood does not just loop around the body once.

buildup.text: The right side of the heart sends blood to the lungs.

discovery.text: There it drops off carbon dioxide and picks up oxygen.

twist.text: Pulmonary arteries are the only arteries carrying used blood.

climax.text: Freshly oxygenated blood returns to the heart's left side.

punchline.text: Even arteries break their own rules here.

quiz.question: What makes pulmonary arteries unique?

hook.text: The left side of the heart has a much bigger job.

buildup.text: It pumps oxygen-rich blood to every organ and tissue.

discovery.text: This loop travels from head to toes and back again.

twist.text: The journey from heart to toe takes only about one minute.

climax.text: Blood returns to the right side, ready for the lungs again.

punchline.text: One minute to travel your whole body.

quiz.question: How long does blood take to travel from heart to toe and back?

hook.text: The heart pumps blood everywhere, but who feeds the heart?

buildup.text: Coronary arteries wrap around the heart's outer surface.

discovery.text: They deliver oxygen and fuel to the heart muscle itself.

twist.text: A blockage in a coronary artery is a heart attack.

climax.text: Doctors can open blocked arteries with tiny balloon stents.

punchline.text: The pump needs its own supply line.

quiz.question: What happens when a coronary artery becomes blocked?

hook.text: Most veins go straight back to the heart after organs.

buildup.text: But blood from the intestines takes a detour first.

discovery.text: The portal vein routes it through the liver for processing.

twist.text: The liver filters toxins before blood rejoins circulation.

climax.text: This explains why liver damage affects the whole body.

punchline.text: Your liver inspects every meal you eat.

quiz.question: Where does the portal vein send blood before it returns to the heart?

hook.text: A baby in the womb cannot breathe with its lungs yet.

buildup.text: Oxygen arrives through the umbilical cord from the mother.

discovery.text: A special hole in the heart lets blood bypass the lungs.

twist.text: At birth, the baby's first breath closes that hole.

climax.text: The entire circulatory route rewires in moments.

punchline.text: One breath rewires the whole system.

quiz.question: How does a fetus get oxygen before birth?

hook.text: A heart attack is not the same as the heart stopping.

buildup.text: It happens when a coronary artery becomes blocked by a clot.

discovery.text: Heart muscle downstream of the block starts to die.

twist.text: Symptoms can be as subtle as jaw pain or nausea.

climax.text: Fast treatment can reopen the artery and save the muscle.

punchline.text: Minutes decide how much heart survives.

quiz.question: What directly causes a heart attack?

hook.text: A stroke is essentially a heart attack in the brain.

buildup.text: A clot or burst vessel cuts blood supply to brain tissue.

discovery.text: Within minutes, brain cells begin to die without oxygen.

twist.text: Acting F-A-S-T checks face, arms, speech, and time.

climax.text: Clot-busting drugs can reverse damage if given in hours.

punchline.text: Time lost is brain lost.

quiz.question: What does the acronym FAST help people recognize?

hook.text: Arteries are not meant to be stiff and narrow.

buildup.text: Fatty plaques slowly build up inside artery walls over years.

discovery.text: These plaques harden and narrow the passage for blood.

twist.text: The process often starts as early as childhood.

climax.text: A plaque can rupture suddenly and trigger a deadly clot.

punchline.text: Decades of buildup, seconds of crisis.

quiz.question: What builds up inside arteries in atherosclerosis?

hook.text: Heart failure does not mean the heart has stopped beating.

buildup.text: It means the heart can no longer pump blood efficiently.

discovery.text: Fluid backs up into the lungs, causing breathlessness.

twist.text: The heart actually enlarges as it tries to compensate.

climax.text: Medications can help, but some patients need transplants.

punchline.text: A struggling heart grows but weakens.

quiz.question: What happens to the heart in heart failure?

hook.text: A healthy heart keeps a steady, predictable rhythm.

buildup.text: Sometimes electrical signals misfire or take wrong paths.

discovery.text: The heart may beat too fast, too slow, or irregularly.

twist.text: Some arrhythmias are harmless, but others can be fatal.

climax.text: A defibrillator shock can reset a dangerously chaotic rhythm.

punchline.text: A jolt of electricity restores order.

quiz.question: What device can reset a dangerous heart rhythm?

hook.text: Your heart is a muscle, and muscles grow with exercise.

buildup.text: Aerobic activity strengthens the heart wall over time.

discovery.text: A stronger heart pumps more blood with fewer beats.

twist.text: Just 30 minutes of walking a day cuts heart risk sharply.

climax.text: Inactivity is now considered as risky as smoking.

punchline.text: Sitting is the new smoking.

quiz.question: How much daily walking can significantly reduce heart risk?

hook.text: Cholesterol is not all bad; your body actually needs it.

buildup.text: LDL cholesterol can deposit fat inside artery walls.

discovery.text: HDL cholesterol carries fat away from arteries to the liver.

twist.text: Eating fiber can lower LDL more than cutting all fat.

climax.text: A balanced diet keeps the LDL-to-HDL ratio healthy.

punchline.text: Good cholesterol cleans up after the bad.

quiz.question: What does HDL cholesterol do?

hook.text: Chronic stress does real physical damage to the heart.

buildup.text: Stress hormones raise blood pressure and heart rate.

discovery.text: Over time this wears down artery walls and the heart.

twist.text: Broken heart syndrome mimics a heart attack from grief.

climax.text: Managing stress is now a key part of cardiac care.

punchline.text: A broken heart is a real diagnosis.

quiz.question: What is broken heart syndrome?
options: A stress reaction mimicking a heart attack

hook.text: Surgeons once thought the beating heart was untouchable.

buildup.text: The heart-lung machine made open-heart surgery possible.

discovery.text: It keeps blood flowing while the heart is stopped.

twist.text: Some surgeries now happen through tiny keyhole incisions.

climax.text: Robotic arms let surgeons operate with extreme precision.

punchline.text: Robots now help fix the human heart.

quiz.question: What invention made open-heart surgery possible?

hook.text: Scientists are working on growing hearts from stem cells.

buildup.text: Lab-grown heart tissue already beats in petri dishes.

discovery.text: 3D-printed scaffolds could shape full replacement hearts.

twist.text: Artificial hearts now let patients live for years waiting.

climax.text: One day a custom-grown heart may end transplant waiting lists.

punchline.text: The future heart may come from a printer.

quiz.question: What technology could help build replacement hearts?
